reviewText:
Much like the film upon which it is based, experiencing Kung Fury: Street Rage is not an intellectual pursuit. Behind its attractively retro flair, complete with simulated bulbous low resolution Cathode Ray Tube display, stylized chiptune music, and sprite graphics, is an unforgiving test of pure reflex. The more you think while playing this game, the worse you'll do! There are only three buttons you need worry about: Right, Left, and Pause. Humorously, pausing the game takes it to a simulated blue screen of death, also providing you with the means to exit the game (pressing start again), causing the screen to warp and snowcrash.

While individual mileage may vary, I find that the wide variety of animations that Kung Fury can unleash to represent your simple one-button attacks to be amusing enough to completely override any semblence of boredom in the otherwise extremely simple concept of the game's mechanics. Its simplicity borders on elegance, or perhaps even meets it, as I do not believe they could have added anything to the game that wouldn't somehow damage the experience.

It boils down to this: enemies run at you from either side and you must attack them as they get close. Most are one-hit mooks easily dispatched, but as play progresses tougher and more complicated enemies arrive--ones that require frantic combinations of right and left attacks to take down, as more and more foes flock and swarm in an attempt to overwhelm you. And overwhelm you they will.

You can take three hits and then it's game over, to start again. There are no power ups, no way to heal yourself, no way to expand your character's capabilities, no other levels; this game is just You, Your Reflexes, and the High Score. Maybe it's not the most immersive experience in the world, but without a doubt it's one of the purest executions of a game ever expressed.

The fact that it's so aesthetically polished--not MERELY poor graphics but an entire suite of stylistic touches like glitches, rendering artifacts, all meant to evoke the limited hardware capacities of ages gone by--makes the whole experience an unexpected treat. Give it a whirl; you don't have anything to lose! ...except for maybe two bucks. But I humbly submit that it's worth that much.

reviewText:
TLDR; Bottom-lineThis game is a Simplified Side Scrolling Arcade Spectacle Brawler. You only have two buttons: Left-attack and Right-attack. The main mechanic is virtually identical to One Finger Death Punch, but in Kung Fury you only have  ONE MODE and ONE STAGE. If this is too little content for you then don't bother. If you want more variety, take a look at One Finger Death Punch. If you liked the movie and want to play as the badass Kung Fury though, this game is still pretty damn fun. I say this game is worth the asking price of $2.

Sample Gameplay
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=454796042

MechanicsThe game is a simplified 2D side scrolling brawler. You have two buttons: [L] Left-Attack and [R] Right-Attack. If enemies come from the left, you hit Left-Attack, if they come from the right you hit Right-Attack. The most common enemy will die in one hit, but other enemies require different combinations of [L] or [R] to defeat. For example the German officer requires you to hit him twice; the blonde girls in white require you to hit them three times in an alternating fashion (From left [L][R][L], from right [R][L][R]).

As for controls you have the choice of using the keyboard keys [A]/[D], or [<-][->], or mouse left-click/right-click. Controllers are also supported, with all the buttons on the left bound to left attack, and all the right buttons bound to right attack. You cannot rebind the keys as there is no options menu.

GraphicsKung Fury is a hyper-stylized 2D side-scroller with an older 1980s pixelated art-style. The viewing area of the game is presented like an old arcade cabinet with a non-flat CRT monitor. The presentation of the game is meant to match the theme of the movie, so if you didn't like the movie or the old CRT look then chances are you won't like the game itself.

StoryGo watch the movie.
The game itself does not have a story, but in order to appreciate this game I recommend watching the movie. It's FREE!

As a side note the game is based on one particular fight scene in the movie, where Kung Fury fights from right to left (side scrolling).

PC Master Race IssuesThere is no options menu. You cannot rebind your keys (though there are a fair amount of default bindings to choose from), and you cannot change your resolution or anything else. The game defaults to fullscreen, but you can change it to window mode by pressing [ALT]+[ENTER]. This is sparse to say the least, and if you are particularly sensitive to missing features such as an options menu, then don't waste your time.

reviewText:
A game like Kung Fury: Street Rage, really doesn't need an overlong review. To start with, this is a two-button game. No I don't mean two buttons like Super Mario Brothers, I mean two buttons: left-attack and right-attack. Enemies approach from both sides, and all you have to do is press the corresponding button to kill them. Your goal? Get a high score. The average game of Kung Fury lasts a minute or two, and it requires only a few seconds to figure out how everything works.

But you want to know something? Despite it's simplistic nature, this is a pretty good game. Kung Fury is all about getting into The Zone and establishing a rhythm. You know about the The Zone right? It's that place you go to where you feel untouchable. It's like gliding in-between billions of bullets, shredding innumerable enemy forces, or in the case of this game, landing dozens if not hundreds of attacks with perfect accuracy at a rapid pace. This is a very focused game, so the simplest mistake is costly. You're only allowed three hits before death and each hit rips into your precious multiplier bonus. Worst of all, taking a hit pulls you out of The Zone. You're about to high-five zen and then suddenly...back to reality...and reality sucks hard.

Since there are only two buttons, your efforts should be focused entirely on your enemies. There are multiple types, each requiring a certain number of attacks before they're killed. There aren't really any recovery frames, so you're free to hit the attack button as much as you want. Of course, if you miss an enemy, you're left wide open (this also depletes your multiplier). This is part of what being in The Zone is all about. You're constantly judging the effective distance of your attacks, the type of enemy, and keeping a mental count of the # of hits/button-presses required to dispatch them. Sometimes it helps to memorize specific button combinations, so you can pull them off immediately on particular enemies. Whatever the cases, this entire process must be handled at a constant rate, and you're given micro-seconds to breathe.

In my experience, this isn't a game that lends itself well to extended play. I usually play Kung Fury until I best my high-score, then move on to another game. While it sounds sensible to keep playing to further improve on that score, it's more effective to quit while I'm ahead. Due to the design of the game, there's a high chance I'll press one too many buttons, or slightly mis-judge the distance of that one enemy, and lose. Repeated failures will lead to burnout. My advice is that once you get that great run, stop, do a little fist pump, then play something else. This is a game you'll want to keep around, even if it's just to get that jolt of action to start your day off right.

It's fair to say that Kung Fury: Street Rage lacks in content, especially compared to the similarly-designed One Finger Death Punch. What you get for your 1.99 is a well-crafted action game with nice aesthetics. This is a quick-fix piece of disposable entertainment, with its long-term value hidden in acquiring high scores as well as giving your gaming-ability a serious workout. It's an altogether solid tie-in with the short movie (which is also entertaining, aside from a weak 2nd act).

Check it out sometime.

reviewText:
At first glance this game is deceptively simple, and even dumb; your only controls are a right attack and a left attack, and all you need to do is wait for an enemy to come close in that direction and press the corresponding key to hit them, The simple two-button design is a clear wink to the arcade games of old. But, like those old arcade games, this one has something intriguing that will make you come back again and again.

So, what is it that makes the game interesting? There is no real goal to reach in the actual gameplay, so the real thing to beat is the high scores list. Find the rhythm and you'll kick off The Hoff. Keep playing, and very soon, you will start getting increasingly aware of exactly which enemies are on either side of you, and even in what order, and you will start to memorize the exact combos to defeat each one. As the game progresses, it adds harder enemies with more interesting combos to beat, and you will get challenged to keep up that perfect combo without missing a single one, to retain that increasingly higher score for each kill. And that challenge is the true charm of this game.

Now excuse me, I need to beat Triceracop's score ;)

reviewText:
The positive reviews of the game before 2016 are no longer accurate, because it isn't the same game.  The original game was a beautiful classic, a perfectly oiled machine.  That game isn't available anymore.  The best way I could describe it is, originally you had a PC game, and they replaced it with a mobile port version of the game.  How else can you explain the game running worse than it used to?   And I'm not talking about fps, I mean the game feels inferior while playing it.

The character you control doesn't handle as well as it once did, the game is not as fluid and responsive as it once was.  The character's perfect responsiveness to your button pressing was the whole point, and that was ruined.  These issues were really really bad when their big update first arrived and people reported and a lot of people including myself noted that we were unable to achieve scores even a quarter as high as we usually did due to poor control responsiveness and other odd shifts to gameplay.  The developers have been slowly trying to fix these issues piecemeal, but so far I still don't feel they have managed to completly repair what they broke.

There were a lot of calls for bringing back the original game, at least as a classic mode.  I notice that those forum posts appear to all be gone, though I don't know if they were deleted or simply are no longer accessible from being a couple months old.  Needless to say, all cries for a classic mode were ignored, and the developer passed out some free keys to some smartphone port game in hopes of silencing things.

I paid money for a game and felt I had gotten more than my money's worth.  Then the developers took that game away and replaced it with something inferior, and while it's close, it's still deep in the uncanny valley.  I can't recommend to anyone what is still just a pale imitation of what was once here.

reviewText:
So everyone talks about the two right and left punches and how those are the only buttons and that's a really fun design. Here is how the game adds depth: As you can probably guess it does so first off buy increasing the number of enemies coming at you from right and left, second of all, there is quite a variety in enemy types; Some simply need one or two hits to take down; other are more complicated. There are enemies that doge around so you need to quickly press the right direction. Missing makes you vulnerable, you slide forward out of position for a moment as you recover, unable to attack. Some enemies are metal, taking a lot of hits forcing you to focus on them and the other one hitters simultaneously. These are just a few examples as the game does a nice job with variety and there are more types than just those I listed. That was the most surprising part for me. On top of the cool music, and combo tracker, there is only one mode (which makes sense), and nice retro feel (they nailed art style and the cool feel when you load up the game and the announcer goes: 'KUNG FURY!').
You loose not because of BS but because you feel you really messed up on timing or because you panicked when seeing a tricky enemy combination and you spazzed out on the buttons, missing, and leaving yourself vulnerable. You have three hitpoints. I have not gotten far enough into the endless mode to see if you ever regain health. Lets find out together! Worth the price. Really fun and simple yet very deep game.

ADDED NOTE: The controls are basically hitting the arrows left or right or the keys (A,D), or the mouse keys. But you can combine to spread your hands out. Exampled: Use 'A' for left attack and use 'right arrow' for right attack. Which I like a lot

Buying this game totally recaptured the feeling of buying a movie tie-in game in the '80s, because just like back then the game turned out to be not what I was expecting.

Okay time to be fair about this. When I saw this game on Steam after justing watching Kung Fury (mind blowing btw) and saw that it appeared to be a homage to Double Dragon/Streets of Rage, I honestly couldn't click through the buying process fast enough. Then when the game started and I was greeted with the retro style Game Intro and Demo Mode, I knew this was going to be awesome. But then came the realisation that there are only two controls to this game, attack left or attack right. Fairly disappointing as I was expecting to be able to freely side scroll along the streets fighting bad guys, but once I'd got over that initial let down the game is still enjoyable. The gameplay is pretty addictive and the simple controls make it perfect to have an idle bash at when I need to kill some time.

For the price I paid for it I wouldn't say I feel ripped off by the game, although if any new content or further development did happen down the line then that would be appreciated (doubt it will happen).

If you're looking for a Beat'em Up in the purest sense of the term then this is your game.

reviewText:
This is a neat little title that pays tribute to the film of the same name, as well as 80's arcade games in general.

Its a painfully simple game but hard to master. You have two attacks - left and right. That's it. No movement, no special power ups. Just manage your attacks as best you can until your three lives run out, and hope you can make a dent on the High Score list.

The aesthetic is awesome - the game plays as if it were on an older arcade cabinet, complete with scanlines and slowdown. The music is nothing too great, but they did include a 16-bit version of one of the songs from the movie (the game's trailer plays it about 12 seconds in - its a good track!)

There's not much else here. Sadly its a shallow game at its core, but overall its a fun time-waster that will push you to reach first place, which is no easy feat. A great homage to games of past, and definitely a great way to spend a couple of bucks to support those who graced us with the Kung Fury movie.

Here's to hoping for more games in the Kung Fury series. Well, I need to head back to the office. Looks like it's gonna be a hell of a lot of paperwork.

Enemies come from both sides and you have to kill them before they hit you. Three hits and you are dead. Simple as that but quite addicting, especially in small dosages.

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game when One Finger Death Punch exists in the same universe. It does nearly everything better (save story), but since gameplay is king, this just doesn't quite cut it.

The pacing is very slow at first, and since the punishment is harsh for failure (back to the start of the wave!) get ready to lose your traction a lot.

The 'hit zone' for where you won't miss isn't clearly marked, so you'll whiff until you decide to just punch enemies as soon as they touch you.

Got as far as the first boss battle, which suddenly and under duress introduces the new mechanic of movement, so suddenly that which caused failure (pressing buttons at the wrong time) is necessary to win. Muddied an already squishy gameflow.

Enemies also approach you in weird ways, so you end up missing sometimes when they decide to possibly change sides(?) behind you.  After getting to the Barbarian (Stage 2), and getting repeatedly disheartened by the pacing, quit and went to OFDP, and suddenly found everything that was missing in this game.

reviewText:
EDIT 2015-12-07

With The Arcade Strikes Back edition, a story mode has been included featuring Hackerman, Barbarina and Triceracop as selectable characters. It is now insanely hilarious! I would now call this a more complete game compared to before. Is it worth full price? HELL YES! The developer really should be supported in this case. I mean they could have done something like many other publishers, like releasing the characters as separate purchaseable DLC, but they did not. So this game is a MUST BUY!

EDIT 2015-06-10

Like some others, I initially bought this game only to show my appreciation for the free and awesome movie. But man, if you haven't played a game of this genre/mechanics before you might be in for an @ss whopping surprise ... literally. In fact I counted my @ss being handed down to me over 650 times.

So you're playing on this street with Hitler's henchmen coming in at you left and right. You just so happen to have only two buttons to press to defend yourself ... left and right arrow keys. But there is an incredible amount of things to learn from button combo's to timing presses. So it goes something like this:

Gas Masked Soldier = 1 hit
Arian Moustache Guy = 2 hits
Shaolin Chick = 3 hits (left, right left OR right left right)
Mechanical Robot = 4 hits
Red Ninja = WTF??? Major distraction!

In essence the game overall is addictive. Even the music is as addictive as Hotline Miami's soundtrack. It's also great in the way that it's a game you can just load up and play with each round lasting (for me) about 2 mins and then exit it really quickly. It isn't feature rich like with options, but that isn't a problem imho. One of the best $2 I've spent.

Now I feel like I have to justify myself, this recommendation is a testimonial to say I must stop playing because it's addictive. It's important to make that distinction. I'm not playing for scores :D I never did. My highest personal expectations was left back from 40,000 to 70,000. Having said that I'd like to point to another recommendation: sauce recommends

reviewText:
This game is simple, awesome, fun, and dangerously addicting. There's literally two buttons, and those are used to attack on either side of you when enemies get in your range. The more attacks you do without missing or getting hit, the more delicious points you rack up. Simple stuff.

Except not really.

Enemies start off hilariously easy. You'll be punching through time travelling nazi skulls like cake at the beginning. Soon enough one punch won't take down certain enemies. Then certain enemies will teleport on the other side of you, so you'll need to respond with a sweet roundhouse, then punch them again when they teleport once more. Then you'll fight robots that take a ton of hits. Then you'll fight kung fu masters who teleport like four times! It just adds onto the insanity that is Kung Fury.

Soon enough you'll start being a kung fu master. You'll learn the combos to take down each enemy, executing them in half-second and you watch yourself tear through each enemy. You'll be so aware on what's on both sides of you you'll grow a third eye just to watch your character punch, kick, shoot, and deliver justice to each and every last enemy.

Once you take your three hits, you start over and try to beat your scores. I keep coming back for mor justice delivering each time.

TL;DR: It's like One Finger Death Punch but with better style and a super rad soundtrack.

reviewText:
For 2 bucks you really can't complain too much about something like this, a licenced retro version of 'One Finger Death Punch Lite'.  It's responsive and is fun although it also mimics the arcade feel by being completely unfair at times.

Don't get me wrong, skill will carry you a long way in this but some of the things OFDP employed to keep itself fair have been omitted including the ability for enemies to group up in one space when one is stunned or sent flying (this happens a LOT with the Kung Fu master enemy who teleports away every two hits) which means that they often hide each other or cause you to strike one enemy pattern and hit another, sometimes this can even cause you to travel through them entirely which will usually cause you to break your combo when you miss and/or take a hit.  You also have no indication or feedback on if an enemy has been damaged at all, which is a problem in a game with only five enemy types in total and where you can knock them past others and even off screen.  Finally, if you get swamped by enemies that swap sides, the game will absolutely not let you spam your way out one side to get breathing room, sometimes giving you a miss despite the fact that there was an enemy so close your whiff passed through them, this can be played around but feels kind of arbitrary.

Also, you can't concentrate too hard as each time you strike an enemy, the screen will flash white.  This is a bizzare inclusion and could lead to players hurting their eyes or worse.  If you suffer from epilepsy in any form, I'm gonna have to recommend giving this one a big miss.

But hey, again, it's only 2 bucks and presents a theoretically unlimited challenge for those who love score attack games and/or just an all around nicer looking package for those who were put off by the overall better (and more expensive) OFDP's presentation.

reviewText:
Loved this.  Surprisingly highly addictive trying to beat my record and master it as it speeds up.

What did I like about this?  Firstly, it captures the look and feel of games I played in my childhood.  Looks, sounds and feels like an old-school arcade game.  Music, design, moves... everything.  Well crafted to recreate the experience.  For the whole Kung Fury experience (movie and promotions) their attention to detail, design, look and feel is phenomenal.

Cool dodgy 80's arcade music, combos, timing and the greatest cop of all time... it's a lot of fun.  And for the price... anyone who complains should take a long hard look at what value they bring to the world.  These guys have brought the past back to life for the same cost of a quick arcade game.  Fun, fast and yeah.  It's a basic arcade button, masher, combo and timing driven game.  For any child of the 80's it's a must!

It's awesome.  I love it and have had a ton of fun with it.  This is my first review on Steam because I want to support these guys for delivering an innovative passion project to the world.

So if you're thinking about it, just do it.  Go on and crack some skulls Streets of Rage style and enjoy.

Ho-lee ♥♥♥♥, how do you ♥♥♥♥ up a two-finger fighting game? Kung Fury: Street Rage is a clone of One Finger Death Punch, with the trademark (and admittedly appealing) Kung Fury styling slapped on top. That's about all you really need to know about the game itself. I loved One Finger Death Punch, so why am I ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off about this one?

The. Controls. Don't. Work.

I know, that sounds ♥♥♥♥ing impossible in a game that uses two buttons, but they don't work! I just installed the game and I can only make Kung Fury attack to the right. I can also only go down in the menus, not up, and they don't wrap around. I've tried every key on my K70 and nothing works.

What's that? Change the bindings at the options  screen? There isn't one! (There might be one hiding somewhere that you need an up arrow to get to, but the main menu has no options.) No graphics options, no control options, nothing. So for my money I basically have a two button game where only one button works. Amazing. Utterly astonishing. I'm a programmer by trade - how inept, lazy or non-existent does your QA team have to be that you can't get the left arrow key working in a game that only uses the arrow keys??

I Googled it, others were having the problem, and they were told to wait for a patch. That was nearly a year ago, and naturally the topic has now been locked because trying to get developer support for your games on Steam is like trying to ♥♥♥♥ a spinning fan.

♥♥♥♥ this game, go buy One Finger Death Punch. It appears to have far more content, and it actually bloody works.

reviewText:
Updated for Arcade Strikes Back: Story mode, voiced by the original cast with new dialogue, and a plotline! It's no longer just going for the high score! New characters to fight with - Barbarianna, who can clear a side with the chain gun every 5 hits, which is awesome; Hackerman, whose ranged weapon knocks back as it charges for a continuous double-damage combo (which often results in wild flailing back and forth as the most effective means of combat); and Triceracop, who...um...seems broken.

You see, Triceracop uses his trademark crotch shot method of attack...with guns...that has the effective range of Kung Fury's normal attacks. I don't know, maybe he's going for a 100% shot to crotch ratio or something and relies on a close range target... However, the guns have a knockback to them, pushing Triceracop backwards. This is fine, until you encounter the wave of kung-fu women who swap sides when hit. The knockback is strong enough to where you can shoot three times in the same direction and still hit them, but not 100% reliably; and you can still alternate your shot directions to hit them... but not 100% reliably. So when the wave of 8 of these women show up (with 2 robot legs) somewhere around the 3rd wave, if your recoil pushes you to the other side of one of these women and your combo breaks, you get stunned, take a hit, and are suddenly surrounded by multiple women (normally a good problem to have) each one having the potential to break your combo if your recoil puts you in the wrong spot to hit, forcing you to take another hit. The game generously provides Triceracop with more hearts than any other character in the game, which makes it feel like the designers were aware the game mechanic caused unavoidable hits.

Original Review below:

Watch the short film, then get the game. The movie is 20 minutes of your life well spent. If you play the game 8 times it pays for itself. I mean, arcade games still cost a quarter per credit, right? A genuine arcade feel to this beat-em-up, with surprisingly in-depth technique for a game that uses only 2 buttons. It's a sort of rhythm of the battle thing - go too fast for the action and you'll end up missing the next enemy and take a hit; go too slow and you'll be surrounded quickly and take a hit. The rhythm fluctuates with the density of enemies and their health. You must be the master of the rhythm of the battle if you want the high score. Wait for the enemy to approach, then buffer your inputs so that no time is wasted preparing for the next enemy. Also digging that retrowave soundtrack.

reviewText:
After the awesomeness that was the movie, I really wanted this game to (at least) be decent; however, I can't in good conscience recommend it because there's another game out there that's almost exactly the same except better in every way.

It's essentially a janky version of One Finger Death Punch, in that there's only two buttons: attack the guy on your left, and attack the guy on your right. Much like OFDP, you start out fighting some basic enemies who only take one hit, and then mix in other enemies who take multiple hits and occasionally dodge to the other side.

The problem is, I'm not entirely sure the developers ever played OFDP - or if they did, they didn't take the time to understand what made OFDP nearly perfect.

See, the key insight that OFDP had is that there's a rhythm to kung-fu fights; there's an ebb and flow, a flurry of action followed by a moment of quiet. This game doesn't have any of that; it goes at the exact same rhythm forever.

And that's completely aside from the fact that One Finger Death Punch took the concept significantly further than this game has, with unlockable skills, weapons, boss fights, and special attacks that send you leaping across the battlefield.

If you already own One Finger Death Punch and want to know how this game is different, go play Blind Survival mode with no skills enabled, then:

Pretend there's no weapons
Pretend there's no boss fights
Pretend the game refuses to be played in a window
Pretend the screen flashes on every single strike, which honestly made me feel kinda sick
Pretend there's no casual racism (which is probably the only upside)
And you'll have an idea of what this game is like.

I'm not saying this due to some misguided idea that this game is ripping off" OFDP - I'm actually very happy that another game's picked up on the ingenious mechanic. I'm just disappointed that this game is strictly worse than One Finger Death Punch."

See also:  Five Finger Death Punch.  Similar style.
Two-button side-scrolling combat game here.  Press one button to attack an enemy on your left, press the other button to attack to the right.  That's it.
Simple?  Yep.
Easy?  Nope.
The whole point is to build up your combo attack chain as high as possible to get the high score and clear the level.  If you miss, your combo chain resets to zero AND you leave yourself open to an attack.  If you get hit, you lose health and your combo chain resets to zero.  You need Jedi-like reflexes to do well with this game.  I can't even get past the second set of levels (where you play as the bad-♥♥♥ Viking babe).  You will automatically switch characters every few levels.  Each character has slightly different attack animations, but the gameplay remains the same throughout.
Character and level design are based on the short film Kung Fury" which I highly suggest you watch.  You don't need to know the story to play this game

True honest: I bought this game only because it was very cheap (1.49E, I wouldn't had even considered it at full price...), and started with very low expectations (I didn't like the movie that much).

This is the typical game you play just to pull the plug for a couple of minutes between more serious activities, and between how fun it is, and how little space it takes, I expect to keep it in my hard drive for quite some time.

Quite recommended for the price-tier.

Gameplay breaks down into two buttons; left mouse (or arrow) and right mouse (or arrow), even though it is so simplistic, the execution is perfect. All you are doing is killing Nazi's with your fists but it gets more complex as you play for example, the most common enemy is a Nazi wearing a gas mask, they die in one hit so they are easy to kill. Next up is a Nazi with blonde hair, they take two hits instead of one. After that you have Nazi women - and once they are in the mix, ♥♥♥♥ goes down - they take three hits to kill but, once you hit them they quickly teleport behind you meaning if you hit them from the right, they end up on your left ready to attack so, you must react quickly to hit them again by switching sides but, like I said before, they take three hits so, they will end up behind you again. After the women comes the Nazi Robots. They take four hits but, if you are not quick to destroy them, they will jump back and gang up with other enemies. Y'know what?  This is fun.

Kung Fury did what it set out to do pretty handily and that was to spoof over-the-top 80's action movies.  And they made it free to watch!  So what more can you do to support these people?  Why not throw a couple dollars their way and get this cool 80's coin-op spoof as an added bonus.

On the surface, the sprites, backgrounds, and effects are spot-on, easily taking me back to Battletoads or Double Dragon and things of the like.

The controls and gameplay are super simple and the action can get overwhelming.  I'm admittedly not that good, but the Hi-scores give me a solid challenge to constantly ram my face into like a brick wall.

Since I bought this game, they recently added three more playable characters, each with their own playstyle, and a story mode (complete with boss battles) with spoken dialogue that's every bit as humorously poorly delivered and written as the movie (and it seems like they retained their original voice actors, or at least really good sound-alikes).  Definitely good for a laugh.

If you enjoy admittedly stupid humor and/or pushing the limits against all odds for that high-scoring run, I'll highly suggest Kung Fury: Street Rage.

reviewText:
One Sentence Review:  Hey look, someone made a bad rip off of a Silver Dollar Game.

Three Sentence Review:  One Finger Death Punch is an excellent game.  You should buy that instead.  It has better mechanics and less bugs.

More In-Depth Review

Take One-Finger Death Punch.  Now remove about 75% of it, and replace stick-men with sprites that have 3-4 attacks in total each.  What you've got left is Kung Fury: Street Rage.  It's not even really graphically superior because of that broken old arcade-machine look they implemented, which gives me more eyestrain than nostalgia.

One Finger Death Punch lets you configure your fighter by selecting 3 skills from a large selection and they all impact the game significantly.  There are also a variety of enemies with different abilities.

Kung Fury: Street Rage has 4 characters.  One standard (no abilities but is the best because said abilities are janky), and then three others with two things that set them apart.  So already a lot less selection than OFDP in terms of variety.  For the most part, you're going to want to stick with the standard as the other three have either crippled health, mechanics that can throw off your rhythm, or both.  Your enemy selection is down to 5 types - standard 1 hit, standard 2 hit, 3-hit dodger, stanard 4 hit, and one guy that takes 5 with a different pattern.  Compare to OFDP which also has a 4-hit dodger, 4 hit standard, brawler, type-switching boss, wackloads of special moves, and a  variety of distinct styles of play.

OFDP has helpful guides and information on its screen.  Kung Fury does not.

OFDP has some really nice musical tracks.  Kung Fury does not.

The only thing that Kung Fury has that OFDP doesn't is a unique boss mode, and that's implemented so poorly it's not a positive thing.  While the core of OFDP is about elminiating positioning and button mashing in favour of precise timing, the boss mode suddenly has you moving about and mashing buttons to survive... but the collisions aren't handled well at all (which is terrible considering the whole 2-button game play is about precision) and the last boss fight was prone to bugging out.

All this could be forgiven if it weren't for the fact that OFDP is already a bargain at full price and offers a lot more game.  By itself it isn't terrible, but considering there's already a game out there that does everything this one except it does it better, bigger and came out first... just get OFDP.  Street Rage won't offer any new experiences.
